doc.previous: Hyderabad's commercial markets are divided into four sectors: central business districts,[150] sub-central business centres, neighbourhood business centres and local business centres.[151] Many traditional and historic bazaars are located throughout the city, Laad Bazaar being the prominent among all is popular for selling a variety of traditional and cultural antique wares, along with gems and pearls.[152][153]
doc.after: The establishment of Indian Drugs and Pharmaceuticals Limited (IDPL), a public sector undertaking, in 1961 was followed over the decades by many national and global companies opening manufacturing and research facilities in the city.[154] As of 2010, the city manufactured one third of India's bulk drugs and 16% of biotechnology products,[155][156] contributing to its reputation as "India's pharmaceutical capital" and the "Genome Valley of India".[157] Hyderabad is a global centre of information technology, for which it is known as Cyberabad (Cyber City).[122][123] As of 2013, it contributed 15% of India's and 98% of Andhra Pradesh's exports in IT and ITES sectors[158] and 22% of NASSCOM's total membership is from the city.[138] The development of HITEC City, a township with extensive technological infrastructure, prompted multinational companies to establish facilities in Hyderabad.[122] The city is home to more than 1300 IT and ITES firms, including global conglomerates such as Microsoft (operating its largest R&D campus outside the US), Google, IBM, Yahoo!, Dell, Facebook,[66]:3[159] and major Indian firms including Tech Mahindra, Infosys, Tata Consultancy Services (TCS) and Wipro.[66]:3 In 2009 the World Bank Group ranked the city as the second best Indian city for doing business.[160] The city and its suburbs contain the highest number of special economic zones of any Indian city.[138]
